tn.text: Jesus has just been talking to the people and his disciples about following him. Six days later, Jesus goes with three of his disciples up a mountain where his appearance changes, so he looks as he will one day in the kingdom of God.
"And Jesus said to his disciples"

tn.ref: the kingdom of God come with power
tn.text: The kingdom of God coming represents God showing himself as king. AT: "God show himself with great power as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The author uses the reflexive pronoun "themselves" here to emphasize that they were alone and that only Jesus, Peter, James, and John went up the mountain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he appeared very different" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"in front of them"
"shining" or "glowing." Jesus' garments were so white they were emitting or putting out light.
"very, very"

tn.ref: whiter than any bleacher on earth could bleach them
tn.text: Bleaching describes the process of making natural white wool even whiter by using chemicals like bleach or ammonia. AT: "whiter than any person on earth could whiten them"
It may be helpful to state who these men are. AT: "two prophets who had lived long ago, Moses and Elijah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "they" refers to Elijah and Moses.

tn.ref: Peter answered and said to Jesus
tn.text: "Peter said to Jesus." Here the word "answered" is used to introduce Peter into the conversation. Peter was not answering a question.
This word refers to Peter, James, and John. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"tents." This refers to simple temporary dwellings.

tn.ref: For he did not know what to say, for they were terrified
tn.text: This parenthetical sentence tells background information about Peter, James, and John. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"very frightened" or "very afraid"
"appeared and covered"

tn.ref: Then a voice came out of the cloud
tn.text: The "voice" is a metonym for God. Also, the "voice" is described as "coming out of the cloud," meaning that they heard God speaking from the cloud. AT: "Then God spoke from the cloud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: This is my beloved Son. Listen to him
tn.text: God the Father expresses his love for his "beloved Son," the Son of God.
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Here "they" refers to Peter, James, and John.

tn.ref: he commanded them to tell no one ... until the Son of Man had risen
tn.text: This implies that he was permitting them to tell people about what they had seen only after he rose from being dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: risen from the dead ones ... to rise from the dead ones
tn.text: "risen from the dead ... to rise from the dead" or "risen from among the dead ones ... to rise from among the dead ones." This means to become alive again. The phrase "the dead ones" refers to "dead people" and is a metaphor for being dead. AT: "risen from being dead ... to rise from being dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: So they kept the matter to themselves
tn.text: Here "kept the matter to themselves" is an idiom that means they did not tell anyone about what they had seen. AT: "So they did not tell anyone about what they had seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Though Peter, James, and John wondered what Jesus might mean by "rising from the dead," they asked him instead about Elijah's coming.
The UDB uses a verse bridge to combine verses 12 and 13, giving the information Jesus is telling them in an order that is easier to understand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_versebridge]])
The word "they" refers to Peter, James, and John.

tn.ref: Why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?
tn.text: Prophecy foretold that Elijah would come again from heaven. Then the Messiah, who is the Son of Man, would come to rule and reign. Other prophecies also foretold that the Son of Man would suffer and be hated by people. The disciples are confused how both could be true.
The scribes taught that Elijah would come back to earth before the Messiah came. AT: "that Elijah must come first before the Messiah comes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Then why is it written ... who is worthless?
tn.text: As Jesus is teaching his disciples, he asks this question and then tells his disciples the answer. This may be expressed as a statement. AT: "But I also want you to consider what is written about the Son of Man. The scriptures say that he must suffer many things and be treated as one who is worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: and be treated as one who is worthless
tn.text: This may be stated in active form. AT: "and people will treat him as one who is worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: and they did whatever they wanted to him
tn.text: It may be helpful to state what people did to him. AT: "and our leaders treated him very badly, just as they wanted to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
When Peter, James, John, and Jesus came down from the mountain, they found the scribes arguing with the other disciples.

tn.ref: they came back to the disciples
tn.text: Jesus, Peter, James, and John returned to the other disciples who had not gone with them up the mountain.
The scribes were arguing with the disciples who had not gone with Jesus.
It may be helpful to state why they were amazed. AT: "was amazed that Jesus had come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

To explain what the scribes and other disciples were arguing about, a father of a demon-possessed man tells Jesus that he has asked the disciples to send the demon out of his son, but they could not. Jesus then casts the demon out of the boy. Later the disciples ask why they were not able to send the demon away.
This means the boy is possessed by an unclean spirit. "He has an unclean spirit" or "He is possessed by an unclean spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
When a person has a seizure, they can have trouble breathing or swallowing. This causes white foam to come out of the mouth. If your language has a way to describe that, you could use it.
"becomes stiff." It may be helpful to state that it is his body that becomes rigid. AT: "his body becomes rigid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "they could not drive it out of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

Though it was the boy's father who made a request of Jesus, Jesus responds to the whole crowd. This can be made clear. AT: "Jesus responded to the crowd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"You unbelieving generation." Jesus calls the crowd this, as he begins to respond to them.

tn.ref: how long will I have to stay with you? ... bear with you?
tn.text: Jesus uses these questions to express his frustration. Both questions have the same meaning. They can be written as statements. AT: "I have become weary by your unbelief!" or "Your unbelief tires me! I wonder how long I must bear with you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"endure you" or "put up with you"
"Bring the boy to me"
This refers to the unclean spirit. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mrk:09:17|9:17]].
This is a condition where a person has no control over his body, and his body shakes violently.
"Since he was a small child." It may be helpful to state this as a full sentence. AT: "He has been like this since he was a small child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"have compassion"

Jesus is rebuking the man's doubt. This question can be written differently or as a statement. AT: "Jesus said to him, "Why do you say, "If you are able"?" or "Jesus said to him, 'You should not have said, "If you are able!"" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "are able to do anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: All things are possible for the one who believes
tn.text: This can be written less abstractly and in active form. AT: "God can do anything for people who believe in him." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"for the person"
This refers to belief in God. AT: "believes in God"
The man is asking Jesus to help him overcome his unbelief and increase his faith. AT: "Help me when I do not believe" or "Help me have more faith"
This means that more people were running toward where Jesus was and that the crowd there was growing larger.
The words "mute" and "deaf" can be explained. AT: "You unclean spirit, you who are causing the boy to be unable to hear and unable to speak"
"The unclean spirit cried out"
"shook the boy violently"
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "came out of the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: The boy looked like one who was dead
tn.text: The boy's appearance is compared to that of a dead person. AT: "The boy appeared dead" or "The boy looked like a dead person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"so that many people"
This means that Jesus grasped the boy's hand with his own hand. AT: "grasped the boy by the hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"helped him get up" (UDB)
This means they were alone.
"cast the unclean spirit out." It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "cast the unclean spirit out of the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: This kind cannot be cast out except by prayer
tn.text: The words "cannot" and "except" are both negative words. In some languages it is more natural to use a positive statement. AT: "This kind can be cast out only by prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
This describes unclean spirits. AT: "This kind of unclean spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Jesus and his disciples left the house where they had been after Jesus had healed the demon-possessed boy. He takes time to teach his disciples alone.
"Jesus and his disciples left that region" (UDB)
"traveled through" or "passed by"

tn.ref: for he was teaching his disciples
tn.text: Jesus was teaching his disciples privately, away from the crowd. This can be stated clearly. AT: "for he was teaching his disciples privately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here Jesus refers to himself as the Son of Man. This is an important title for Jesus. "I, the Son of Man," (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Here "hands" is a metonym for control. AT: "into the control of men" or "to the control of men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: When he has been put to death, after three days
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "After they have put him to death and three days have passed," (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they were afraid to ask him
tn.text: They were afraid to ask Jesus what his statement meant. AT: "they were afraid to ask him what it meant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
When they come to Capernaum, Jesus teaches his disciples about being humble servants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"they arrived at." The word "they" refers to Jesus and his disciples.
"discussing with one another"
They were silent because they were ashamed to tell Jesus what they had been discussing. AT: "they were silent because they were ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "who was the greatest among them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: If anyone wants to be first, he must be last of all
tn.text: Here the words "first" and "last" are opposites of one another. Jesus speaks of being the "most important" as being "first" and of being the "least important" as being "last." AT: "If anyone wants God to consider him to be the most important person of all, he must consider himself to be the least important of all" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"of all people ... of all people"
"among them" (UDB). The word "their" refers to the crowd.

tn.ref: He took him in his arms
tn.text: This means that he hugged the child or picked him up and placed him on his lap.
"a child like this"
This means to do something because of love for Jesus. AT: "because they love me" (UDB) or "for my sake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to God who has sent him to earth. AT: "God who has sent me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"John said to Jesus"
"sending away demons." This refers to casting demons out of people. AT: "driving demons out of people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "name" is associated with Jesus' authority and power. AT: "by the authority of your name" or "by the power of your name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means that he is not among their group of disciples. AT: "he is not one of us" or "he does not walk with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"is not opposing us"
It can be explained clearly what this means. AT: "is trying to achieve the same goals that we are" (UDB)

tn.ref: gives you a cup of water to drink because you belong to Christ
tn.text: Jesus speaks about giving someone a cup of water as an example of how one person may help another. This is a metaphor for helping someone in any way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This negative sentence emphasizes the positive meaning. In some languages, it is more natural to use a positive statement. AT: "definitely receive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
a large, round stone used for grinding grain into flour

tn.ref: If your hand causes you to stumble
tn.text: Here "hand" is a metonym for desiring to do something sinful that you would do with your hand. AT: "If you want to do something sinful with one of your hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to be maimed and then to enter into life" or "to be maimed before entering into life"
Dying and then beginning to live eternally is spoken of as entering into life. AT: "to enter into eternal life" or "to die and begin to live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
missing a body part as a result of having it removed or being injured. Here it refers to missing a hand. AT: "without a hand" or "missing a hand"
"where the fire cannot be put out"

tn.ref: If your foot causes you to stumble
tn.text: Here the word "foot" is a metonym for desiring to do something sinful that you would do with your feet, such as going to a place you should not go to. AT: "If you want to do something sinful with one of your feet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to be lame and then to enter into life" or "to be lame before entering into life"
Dying and then beginning to live eternally  is spoken of as entering into life. AT: "to enter into eternal life" or "to die and begin to live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"unable to walk easily." Here it refers not being able to walk well because of missing a foot. AT: "without a foot" or "missing a foot"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "and for God to throw you into hell" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: If your eye causes you to stumble, tear it out
tn.text: Here the word "eye" is a metonym for either 1) desiring to sin by looking at something. AT: "If you want to do something sinful by looking at something, tear your eye out."  Or 2) Desiring to sin because of what you have looked at. AT: "If you want to do something sinful because of what you look at, tear your eye out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to enter into the kingdom of God with one eye than to have two eyes
tn.text: This refers to the state of a person's physical body when he dies. A person does not take his physical body with him into eternity. AT: "to enter into the kingdom of God, after having lived on earth with only one eye, than to have lived on earth and had two eyes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in the active form. AT: "for God to throw you into hell" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: where their worm does not die
tn.text: The meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "where worms that eat  people there do not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: everyone will be salted with fire
tn.text: Here Jesus speaks of everyone being purified by experiencing suffering. Jesus speaks of suffering as if it were fire and giving suffering to people as if it were applying salt to them. This can be stated also in active form. AT: "Just as salt purifies a sacrifice, God will purify everyone by allowing them to suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"its salty taste"

tn.ref: how can you make it salty again?
tn.text: This can be written as a statement. AT: "you cannot make it salty again." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"taste salty again"

Jesus speaks of doing good things for one another as if good things were salt that people possess. AT: "Do good to each other, like salt adds flavor to food" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
